head: How Americans describe what society values (and doesnâ€™t) in each gender
sub:
This project challenged me as a designer, developer and storyteller.

Ensuring that the writing and visual flow were seamless, I introduced Figma as a new tool and workflow for the project's writer, data scientist and editors, who could write within the designs and iterate alongside me in live time.

I also learned to write custom, animated d3.js charts from scratch to build this data visualization. And I taught myself Semantic UI's visibility callbacks to trigger animations.

head: Dallas' hidden history
sub:
Inspired by Google's UI designs and excited to experiment with node.js and Mapbox's API, I stepped up to build this map application that was requested by the Dallas Morning News opinion desk.

I had never created anything with user input (nor anything that had a back-end approval UI) so imagining use-case scenarios and planning for the dynamic nature of the page was an exciting exercise.

head: The helmet conundrum
sub:
As the designer and developer for this project, I also stepped up as the unofficial project manager, ensuring that illustrators, writers, data reporters and photographers could create one, cohesive investigative package.

When designing this, I was thoughtful about how to indicate that this was a chaptered story. You'll see my use of menus (at the beginning) and chapter cards (at the end) as a solution for moving users through the package.

head: Interactive bubble map of countries by state religion status
sub: This project strengthened my d3.js and data manipulation skills, as I adapted a base d3 project and built a lookup interface that synced the data with Firebase.

head: The rise and fall of the 'Frack Master'
sub: Designing and coding an experience that kept readers scrolling was the greatest challenge of this longer piece. To tackle this problem, I created a navigation that indicated progress as readers scrolled deeper in the story. I also created section headers to tease the upcoming content and provide visual relief between text wells.

head: The 100 highest-paid CEOs in Dallas-Fort Worth
sub: I learned to use AJAX and d3.js to make a simple chart (with filtering buttons!).

head: From farm to your table
sub: This project could have been a simple recipe listicle. But in the spirit of learning, I created an interactive, visually fun layout and sticky navigation that allowed me to write a project in Sass for the first time, and to practice JavaScript loops and conditionals.

head: Meet the dogs who helped us cope after the Dallas police ambush
sub: I learned to implement some simple flip-card designs using CSS animations for a heart-warming feature to follow the police shooting.
